The lanthanide elements are located in the bottom left corner of the periodic table and are also known as the rare earth elements. These elements are generally more stable than the actinide elements, which are located in the bottom right corner of the periodic table. The lanthanide elements have a higher ionization energy and a lower electronegativity than the actinide elements, which means they are less likely to lose or gain electrons. This higher stability makes the lanthanide elements more resistant to radioactive decay and more likely to form compounds with other elements.
On the other hand, the actinide elements are more reactive and have a lower stability than the lanthanide elements. They have a lower ionization energy and a higher electronegativity, which means they are more likely to lose or gain electrons. This higher reactivity makes the actinide elements more prone to radioactive decay and less likely to form compounds with other elements.
